column5: Topwater for me, and in particular, fishing with buzzbaits. You see the hits, you feel the hits, and a lot of the time you actually see the fish coming before they completely crush it. That's utopia.
I thought you were going to say icefishing  :)
Its a toss up between netting and spearing...dont make me choose.  My favorite 'style' is adapting to what the fish want, and (sometimes) reaping the rewards.

My favourite technique varies as the year goes on. In a few weeks my favourite tactic will be buzzbaits in the stumps for bass, then fall will come and I may favour tube jigs, or giant spinnerbaits  It's ALL exciting, as long as a line's in the water I'm doing my favourite technique.

Sight fishing to a school of 3 to 6+ lb. Brookies in crystal clear water. Some days you can pick which fish you want to catch, and other days you can't get one of them to commit if your life depended on it. But always such a rush!
Dan, I'm hoping to see schools of those little sharks one day...  Me and the oldman would probably lose our minds, lol!
Six week long trips... have only seen that once Dan.  What a crazy sight to see too.  Hopefully will again sometime.  Because you're right, casting to those fish is an awesome experience.

I've seen it plenty of times Drew, but only once in twenty years have I experienced the "pick which fish you want to catch" thing. What a fantastic experience. The frustrating part was when you threw a jig in front of a 6 or 7 lb. fish and a 3 pounder darts out of nowhere and inhales your jig. Pure awesomeness nonetheless.

Touche Dan.  Funny, the 3 of us were looking at dozens of fish throughout the afternoon but they had lock-jaw.  Come that evening they were still all around everywhere, but in our short couple hour window when they bit, we picked up 9.  Thought that was awesome because it was our first trip, and then you and Wayne arrived.  Great time had.

I've been over schools that wouldn't touch a thing for 4 days straight Drew. Frustrating to say the least. You never know when that magic moment will come. But when it does, the saying "heaven on earth" never had so much meaning.

I'm the frog master...I can't spend a day bass fishing without any less than 9 or 10 different rods and baits in front of me but Flipping and Pitching plastics, jigs and punch rigs has to be 2nd place for me. Heavy braids and no messing around. Finesse fishing at it's best, put the trolling motor down pick apart the cover and get ready.  Slop Froggin is #1 for me!! I still rather fight a largie on heavy braid a mile out Froggin than 20ft out in front of me.
LOL ... nope. Problem with ice fishing is that it takes way too long to make a hole big enough to fit the boat in.
fly fishing either with wet flies or swinging steelhead flies.
Twitch, twitch, SMASH  I love jerkbaiting for pike (or musky if they are around)
Senko for largies and drop-shotting for smallies.
jerkbaits for pike, top water for anything, senkos for bass
Trolling spoons for pike, and when the conditions are right topwater poppers for bass!!

I have to commit to using topwaters for musky more this year. I usually give up though because I see something following it and it turns out it's just a smallmouth. Or seagulls take an interest in it and I have to put it away or else I'll catch them.

toss up, love watching a float go down for steelhead but also love wading out and tossing top waters in the evenings for bass and pike. A close 3rd would be running for a tip up watching it going down.
Anything and I do mean anything except trolling unless downriggers are in use.

hard to pick...generally anything sight fishing  fly casting to spring pike  tarpon (yet to land sadly...it's like a 150lb steelhead on steroids, my favourite fish)  the first sturgeon i caught was fun, after that it becomes a chore/workout lol
paddling my canoe around a brookie lake trolling spoons and casting the shore with spinners/raps.
passion in every post. i love that. mines trollin muskies. its a science if done well.

They still got lots of dust on them??  I love doing it all but topwater for any fish is pretty exciting.  Flippin' and pitchin', casting spinnerbaits and cranks, ripping bucktails, finesse fishing, trolling....they all have a time and a place throughout the year.  I should break out the fly gear this year, it's been a while since that's been used.
YUPPPP

how bout old school cod jig 400 ft line toss the big jig overboard and wear yourself out catching cod off the coast of nfld all handline fishing...wish I was kid again....lol for a treat we would row into a secluded bay and go brookie in a creek that seen very few humans if any at all twig. line. hook. find a worm or grub you were set after 1st trout bait was the fins on a hook

seen old man neatest stl I have ever seen 10 ft cane pole 10 ft mono line dunking weeds for walleye now the neat part,,,when he got a hit set the hook thew pole in the lake when the fish wore itself out dragging the pole old man rowed over picked pole out of lake and boated the fish this happened all morn till he got his limit...
Cool style, doesn't sound like much fun though
he was having a blast.. great guy I even gave him Cpl jigs I was catching fish on

Drop shoting slammers for smallies. They'll rip the rod right outta your hand if you aren't careful. Trolling flat line for walleye with Mike Rousseau  Casting spinnerbaits for anything that bites, especially Pike.
1- Float tubing for giant specks... you just can't beat that.  2- Night shore fishing for giant eyes in the fall.
Woot .. my spoon today!
Nice shootin TJ !!!!! Awesome pike ......it always feel better when you catch a fish on your own lure creations !!!!!! Cheers

All types of fishin, just some are better than others. Jigging finicky Walleye has to be the better for me on a quiet lake nobody around with a few buds, feet up, in the boat telling old stories of years past and buds that have past, maybe catching an odd fish, back at the cottage havin the fish fry, few brews sitting around telling more stories around the campfire. Life is good but too short.
You pretty well summed it all up right there Dave !!

so far in Canada i would have to say straight jigging for trout and walleye in deep water, ice fishing for lakers and whitefish with a jig aint to shabby either , so i guess i would have to say JIGGING.
Could spend all day trolling likely structure for muskies, or throwing topwaters for bass/musky.
I'm a total nut for flipping and dunking jigs in the thickest weed I can find find that a variety of fish live where you can hardly get a lure
Spinner fishing creeks for speckles with lots of cover. Ice fishing comes second but nor by much.
memories of nfld..isolated creek brookie fishing
Casting the shoreline and working docks for bass and pike and if my shoulder is acting up trolling for what ever.  vance
Casting either buck tails or jerk baits for musky, or casting husky jerks for whatever will bite. That's fun because you never know for sure what it is when you first feel that strike.
Trolling for walleyes !!!! Senko fishing for bass !!!!!
Topwater Muskie mayhem!  Hard to beat
nymphing fast water for steelhead, casting shorlines for bass and pike, and fishing weightless plastics for bass (preferably smallmouth  )
Top water on nice calm morning for bass.
Ditto. Watching the swirl of water and hearing the smash is a thrill I can't get enough of.
Sight fishing a flat with the fly rod . Preferably somewhere tropical.
Jigging deep water lake trout .
Trolling walleye... Flatline... Rod in hand... On structure... Slamming bottom... With cranks....   Ooohhhhh baby...
Fishing for anything using a float. A buddy who got me into fishing for chrome always said the best part is watching the float go down.  All these years later and I still agree.
popping bucktails for wally's.
Warm weather months is casting large bucktails,  spinnerbaits & jerkbaits for muskies and when it gets colder it's lotsa trolling with big body baits.
Anchored up and jigging for eyes.

Flipping jigs into trees and deep weeds for bass Jerkbait fishing for smallies and pike Ripping bucktail jigs for walleye Topwater for bass Skipping docks for bass Float fishing frog water for steelhead
~~~~Drop shotten, slow and easy tight to the bottom
I love fishing topwaters for bass, love float fishing for steelhead in the fall.  However, it doesn't get much better then tossing mouse patterns to big brookies on the 6wt.
I like it all. The hardest part is deciding what to do most days! We're spoiled rotten here in ontario. Soooo many awesome fishing opportunities!!  S.
My go to is definitley Spinnerbait fishing for Bass. I don't know why but it just seems to be my confidence lure.  I love watching Bass smoke a Buzzbait or Frog though. That never gets old.
Float fishing for steelhead.
